title: AtoZ CSS News
tag_line: My favourite articles and news plus a new CSS tip
subject_line: AtoZ CSS: Specificity, Naming things, Sass resources, Angled edges and more!
intro_text: It's been a busy week of 5am starts but never fear, CSS News is here - a day late but here never the less. Here's a selection of interesting things I came across over the last few days. Enjoy!

news.link_text: Do we actually need Specificity in CSS?
news.link_comment: Having just taught a class on specificity, this title caught my eye. @philipwalton has been featured here before and this is yet another exceptionally written article. It's an interesting question to pose and I expect one day we'll talk about the 'back in the day' when we had to deal with specificity. Interesting stuff.

If you like your content jam-packed full of value then this round up from CSS Author has it in buckets. Frameworks, grids, compilers, components, plugins, generators, libraries and loads more have all been compiled into a vast list and split up into categories. Let's hope the AtoZ CSS Sass course makes it to the list next year!

You've probably heard the age-old quote about the hardest thing in programming (naming things) but in this short and sweet post, Reda from Thoughtbot outlines a solid way of handling naming of colours in CSS variables. I tend to use naming conventions but this method looks worth a shot for sure.

news.link_text: Angled edges with CSS masks and transforms
news.link_comment: And now for something more practical. In this tutorial from Viget, Jeremy experiments with pseudo elements and the transform and clip path properties to make some interesting shapes. I'm designing a very angular and polygon-style site at the moment and there's some great tips in here for doing just that.

I don't know about you, but bezier curves have always been my downfall whenever I try and turn my hand to design. They confuse the hell out of me! This tool could go a good way to helping me understand what's really going on though. Not only is this tool useful, it's beautifully designed. I highly recommend checking it out.
